title: Research on the GST gene family in Salix lindleyana reveals Trp162 and Pro202 as key amino acids controlling the release rate of GS-X.
abstract_text: The adaptive evolution of the glutathione S-transferase (GST) gene family in Salix lindleyana provides insights into the relationship between enzyme structure and function. In this study, 37 genes encoding the GST protein were cloned from S. lindleyana with no genomic data available, and their expression levels and enzyme activity were determined in vitro. The 22 genes encoding the Tau GST subfamily were divided into Clades A and B, with Clade A subjected to more relaxed selection pressure than Clade B. Clade A was split into two smaller branches, Clades a and b. Three genes under positive selection from Clade a were chosen for 36 site-directed mutations, with Trp162 and Pro202 crucially affecting variations in GST enzyme activity. Crystal structure analysis of SliGSTU7 complexed with GSH revealed that the Trp162 residue was located at the bottom of the hydrophobic cavity. Homology modeling and molecular docking revealed that the W162G/P202A mutation in SliGSTU7 significantly reduced the neighboring effect during the formation of GS-DNB. A study of the GST gene family of S. lindleyana identified Trp162 and Pro202 as key amino acids that regulate the release rate of GS-X.

Studies have shown that various environmental stimuli, such as biological stress (e.g., fungal inducers and pathogen invasion) [ 2 ] and abiotic stress (e.g., cold, drought, H 2 O 2 , and hormone treatment) [ 3 ], can induce GST expression. Two subunits of GST form a globular dimer [ 4 , 5 ], with each subunit containing an N-terminal domain and a C-terminal domain entirely comprising α-helices. The C-terminal domain is linked to the N-terminal domain by a sequence of approximately 10 residues. In this structure, the N-terminal domain of one subunit interacts with the C-terminal domain of another subunit, which is crucial for maintaining the enzyme’s stability and function. GST can catalyze the binding reaction between various substrates and glutathione (GSH), reduce organic hydroperoxide, or promote the isomerization of substrates [ 6 ]. Unlike the conserved N-terminal domain, the C-terminal domain’s sequence and topological structure vary greatly, leading to different substrate specificities at the H-terminal domain [ 7 ]. GSTs also have a ligand binding site (L-site) to bind to hydrophobic substrates; thus, they can also be used as carriers to transport proteins and play a wider role by carrying and transporting various metabolites, such as plant hormones, anthocyanins, flavonoids, porphyrins, and other secondary metabolites [ 8 , 9 ]. Glutathione thiotransferase is a key enzyme that plays a metabolic detoxification role in organisms; its main function is to catalyze GSH to form conjugates with harmful exogenous substances. The H-site of GSTs is highly polymorphic; thus, GSTs can theoretically bind hundreds of different toxic molecules to GSH, indicating their wide application value. GSTs can be combined with many exogenous organisms, including herbicides, drugs, and organic pollutants involved in electrophilic reactions. These compounds usually have a common feature: a carbon‒carbon double bond adjacent to an electronic group (Michael acceptor). For example, some nitroaromatic compounds, such as 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (CDNB), p-nitrobenzyl chloride, ethylacrylic acid, and benzyl isothiocyanate [ 10 ], are substrates of GSTs. These compounds can be effectively excreted from the body after being catalyzed by GSTs to form conjugates with GSH, thus reducing their harm to the organism. Glutathione is the first substrate of GST, and its G-site binding site is highly conserved. The G-site also promotes the sulfhydryl ionization of glutathione through hydrogen bonding with adjacent hydroxyl groups, resulting in highly active sulfate anions. For example, in ZmGSTF1-1, this hydrogen bond activation reduces the thiol dissociation constant ( pKa ) from 8.7 to 6.2 [ 11 ]. The activation and stability of glutathione are realized by the hydrogen bond provided by the hydroxyl group of the glutathione mercaptotransferase Tyr/Ser residue to the thio group of glutathione. Site-directed mutation of Tyr and Ser [ 5 , 12 ] causes the enzyme to lose its catalytic activity, confirming the important role of these residues in GST catalysis. The H-site is highly variable and can accept many different hydrophobic substrates. According to the known enzyme kinetics of the GSH-conjugated model xenobiotic substrate, these reactions are predicted to involve a random sequence of two substrates and two products, and the overall reaction rate is determined by the rate at which the active site releases the reaction products [ 11 ]. The catalytic diversity of GSTs is related to the structural variability, heterogeneity, and conformational variability of the G- and H-sites [ 13 , 14 ]. Some researchers believe that the structural dynamic change in GSTs is related to their catalytic mechanism, which allows different substrate structures to be identified with minimum energy cost. The functional fate of repeated genes produced by gene duplication includes neofunctionalization, subfunctionalization, and pseudogeneization. Duplicate genes may also have undergone other evolutionary processes, such as gene fusion and recombination. Thus, the fate of repeated genes in the genome is complicated and diverse. The GST gene family is usually large in scale, and dozens of GSTs belong to different categories in most species. In the early 1990 s, the first evolutionary model of GST was proposed, in which typical soluble GSTs in plants, animals, and fungi were derived from the ancestral genes of Theta-like GSTs through repeated evolution and differentiation [ 15 ]. However, further research challenged this model in subsequent years. Researchers have begun to focus on the biological characteristics of GSTs, including the properties of their catalytic residues and the state and three-dimensional structure of protein oligomers [ 16 ], and have proposed new viewpoints. Current significant gaps persist in the understanding of GST protein evolution and function. Although the new model proposes that soluble GSTs evolved from TRX/GRX ancestors by acquiring an extended C-terminal domain, this hypothesis remains empirically untested in extremophile species adapted to harsh environments. Furthermore, how GST gene family members regulate dual-substrate catalytic mechanisms under natural selection pressure remains unknown. This lack of knowledge regarding structure-function relationships limits our comprehension of the molecular underpinnings of GST environmental adaptation and evolution. This research focuses on the alpine species Salix lindleyana as the primary model organism, with the objective of investigating the correlation between the catalytic efficiency of enzyme proteins and their structural characteristics. This is achieved through the identification and analysis of amino acid mutations within the gene family members that have accumulated as a result of evolutionary adaptations to environmental stressors under selective pressure. Furthermore, the study aims to elucidate the structural foundations that facilitate the efficient catalysis of these enzyme proteins, as well as to examine the dual-substrate catalytic mechanisms employed by GST-encoded enzymes. Materials and methods Plant material and growth conditions Salix lindleyana Wall. & Andersson plants were collected from Kangding City, Ganzi Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, China, at an altitude of 4010 m with coordinates of 29°54′18″N, 102°0′7″E (Fig. S1). Samples were collected from the root, stem, leaf, flower, and pod, with priority given to vigorous, rapidly growing specimens. Three biological replicates were obtained for each sample. The collected samples were then preserved in RNA Later stabilization solution (Invitrogen, USA) and transported on dry ice. A specimen was deposited at the herbarium of Beijing Forestry University (http://bjfc,bjfu,edu.cn2, Zhi-Xiang Zhang, zxzhang@bjfu.edu.cn) under the voucher number BFC00099886. Cloning and phylogenetic analysis of the GSTs of Salix lindleyana Salix brachista is a related species of Salix lindleyana . Using the full-length GST genes of Populus tomentosa as a template, in the newly published Salix brachista genome [ 17 ], local BLAST was conducted via the TBLASTN program to search for candidate GST genes in the Salix brachista genome. To obtain as many GST members of Salix lindleyana as possible, we designed primers based on the GST gene sequences of Salix brachista (Table S1) and amplified the GST genes with the cDNA of Salix lindleyana as a template. The amplified gene sequences were detected by Taihe Biotechnology Co., Ltd., and accurate sequences were obtained. The amino acid sequences of Populus tomentosa GSTs and Salix paliurus GSTs were compared via the MAFFT ( https://MAFFT.cbrc.jp/alignment/server/ ) website. The compared sequences were manually corrected using BioEdit Sequence Alignment Editor software [ 18 ]. The phylogenetic tree was constructed using the maximum likelihood (ML) method in PhyML 3.0 software [ 19 ], and the Jones‒Taylor‒Thornton model was selected as the amino acid substitution model. The number of bootstraps was set to 1000. Escherichia coli GRX2 [ 20 ] was used as an outgroup. Expression patterns of Salix lindleyana GST genes On July 25, 2021, we observed that Salix lindleyana was in a flowering and fruiting life cycle. We collected the roots, stems, leaves, flowers, and pods of wild Salix lindleyana in the same growth environment and conditions as the other samples, and each sample was set up in three biological replicates. During the sampling process, samples demonstrating vigorous growth were quickly selected, and the surfaces of the samples were quickly cleaned with RNase-free water. After the surface mixture was absorbed, the samples were placed in enzyme-free tubes and finally stored in RNA later stabilization solution (Invitrogen, USA). The samples were protected by dry ice during transportation. A total RNA library of Salix lindleyana was constructed, and its quality was tested. The RNA samples were sequenced, and then the quality of RNA-seq data was controlled. The quality control software used was fastp (version 0.19.7), with the parameters set as follows: fastp -g -q 5 -u 50 -n 15 -l 150. Sequence alignment to the reference genome: The reference genome data of Salix brachista were downloaded from BioProject accession number PRJNA472210 in the NCBI database. The reference genome index was constructed using HISAT2 (v2.0.5), and the double-ended clean reads were compared with the reference genome. BLAST was conducted on the GST genes (Table S2) identified in Salix brachista in the Salix lindleyana transcription group. The gene expression levels of the sequences obtained via BLAST were subsequently quantified. The feature count (1.5.0-P3) was used to calculate the number of reads mapped to each gene. Then, the fragments per kilobase of transcript per million mapped reads (FPKM) of each gene was calculated according to the length of the gene, the expression data obtained were normalized by log10 (FPKM), and a heatmap was drawn using the heatmap tool. Expression and purification of Salix lindleyana GST proteins In this study, the cloned GST genes of Salix lindleyana were subcloned and inserted into the prokaryotic expression vector pET30a1 via homologous recombination using a Uniclone One-Step Seamless Cloning Kit. The N-terminus of the protein carried six His tags, which were further purified using a nickel column. The pET30a1 vector was digested with the restriction enzymes Eco RI/ Sal I, Bam HI/ Sal I, and Bam HI/ Sac I, and the purified GST genes of Salix lindleyana were fragmented and recombined with the linear pET30a1 vector. After sequencing, the recombinant plasmid was transformed into BL21 (DE3) competent cells. In an aseptic environment, 7 mL of resuscitated bacterial mixture was transferred to 700 mL of LB liquid medium containing 30 mg/mL Kana antibiotic and cultured with shaking at 37°C and 220 rpm. When the OD600 of the bacterial mixture was 0.6, 0.8 M IPTG was added to a final concentration of 0.08 mM. Protein expression was induced at a low temperature of 20°C and cultured overnight at 180 rpm. The nickel column (GE Healthcare BioSciences) was washed with binding buffer three to four times to balance the column. After 12 h of induction, the bacteria were collected by centrifugation at 3900 rpm for 15 min at 4°C. After the cells were resuspended in precooled binding buffer on ice, they were crushed for 30 min at 6% power, with each cycle consisting of 1.5 s of sonication followed by a 1.5-second interval. After crushing, the supernatant was collected by centrifugation at 4°C and 8800 rpm for 12 min. The supernatant was chelated with nickel column material and incubated on ice for 45 min. The protein impurities were washed with binding buffer precooled on ice. An elution buffer precooled on ice was used to elute the protein. Enzyme assays and kinetic constants of Salix lindleyana GST enzymes In this study, the enzymatic activity and substrate specificity of GST were assessed via four common substrates: CDNB (1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene), NBD-Cl (7-chloro-4-nitrobenzo-2-oxa-1,3-diazole), DHA (dehydroascorbate), and fluorodifen. The determination method for CDNB was based on the study of Habig [ 21 ]; the determination method for NBD-Cl followed the study of Ricci [ 22 ]; and the determination method for fluorodifen was described by Edwards and Dixon [ 23 ]. The first substrate in sex determination is GSH (L-reduced glutathione). The K m and k cat values of the recombinant protein to the GSH or CDNB substrate were determined, the concentration of CDNB as the second substrate was fixed at 1 mM, and the kinetic parameters of GSH as the first substrate were determined. The concentration of GSH varied from 0.25 mM to 4 mm. Conversely, the concentration of GSH in the first substrate was fixed at 1 mM, and the kinetic parameters of CDNB in the second substrate were determined. The concentration range of CDNB was 0.25–4 mM. At least three replicates were performed for determining the activity at each concentration. Nonlinear regression analysis of the dynamic parameters was performed using the Hyper32 program, and the dynamic parameters were calculated using GraphPad Prism 7. Selection pressure analysis of Salix lindleyana Tau GSTs In this study, the YN00 program in the PAML software package 4.3 was used to calculate the ω ( ω = d N /d S ) value for each pair of amino acid sequences of Tau GSTs. The sequences of the N-terminal domain (the 1st–78th positions of the Tau GST alignment sequence) and the C-terminal domain (the 90th-last positions of the Tau GST alignment sequence) were calculated. A t test was used to determine whether the ω values of the two domains were significantly different [ 24 ]. The GSTs of the Tau subfamily are divided into two branches. PAML software CODEML was used to test and set up two models to test whether the selection pressure between branches of the phylogenetic tree of the Tau GST system is the same [ 24 ]. These models comprised a one-ratio model, in which all branches had the same ω value, and a two-ratio model, which assumed that each branch had a different ω value. Two branching site models (A0 and A) were used to test whether some amino acid sites in Clade A were positively selected. Clades a and b are divided into foreground and background branches, respectively. Model A allowed ω to change between sites of the foreground branch, whereas model A0 did not allow positive selection; instead, ω was fixed at 1. The forward selection (A) and neutral (A0) branching site models were evaluated using the likelihood ratio test. Then, the empirical Bayesian method [ 25 ] was applied to the results of Model A to identify candidate positive selection sites. Site-directed mutation of the amino acid sequence Site mutants were obtained via site-directed mutagenesis [ 26 ]. Primers (Table S3) were designed at the positions where point mutations were needed, and the mutant clones of the pET30a1-SliGSTU7 and pET30a1-SliGSTU14 vectors were generated using the full-form Gold Fast Mutagenesis System Kit. The following were added to the total system: 1 µL of plasmid, 12.5 µL of 2× TransStart ® FastPfu Fly PCR SuperMix, 1 µL of site-directed mutagenesis primer F, 1 µL of site-directed mutagenesis primer R, and 4.5 µL of sterile water. After cloning, the complete plasmid was obtained, and the mutation site was checked by sequencing. Thermodynamic stability analysis of proteins Four proteins, the wild-type and mutant SliGSTU7 and SliGSTU14 proteins, were purified, and the elution buffer was subsequently replaced with HEPES-Na buffer via a PD-10 desalting column filled with Sephadex G-25 resin. Before loading the sample, the protein concentration was diluted to approximately 1 mg/ml. For the experimental process, please refer to the operation method of Qu [ 26 ]. To ensure no impurities in the sample affected the experimental results, the sample was centrifuged at 12,000 rpm for 10 min before loading. After the protein sample and HEPES-Na buffer were injected, the temperature range was set at 20–100°C, and the heating rate was 2°C/min. After the machine was rinsed with ddH 2 O, the mechanical arm first drew two reacted HEPES-Na buffers for baseline calibration, followed by the suction of 200 µL protein samples for heat scanning. After the scanning was completed, ddH 2 O was used for cleaning. The data were automatically analyzed and plotted in the supporting software. Crystallization, data collection, and processing To obtain crystals of protein combined with the first substrate, 10 mM GSH was added to the elution buffer. After the protein mixture purified with a nickel column was filtered through a 0.22 µM filter membrane, the protein mixture was concentrated to 6 mL in an Amicon Ultra15 ultrafiltration centrifuge tube (Millipore, Germany), the concentration of the protein was determined, and 50 µL of each protein sample was taken. The supernatant was added to a HiloadTMSuperdexTM200 pg 16/600 GL column (GE Healthcare, Sweden) and then eluted with 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) buffer containing 10 mM GSH. In this study, the crystallization of the GST protein was performed via the hanging drop method using the following procedure. First, 200 µL of buffer from the initial screening kit was added to each well of the crystallization plate as the reservoir solution. Two microliters of the reservoir solution was mixed with 2 µL of protein mixture (with protein concentrations of 0, 10, 15, and 20 mg/mL; the mixture contained 10 mM Tris-HCl at pH 7.4 and 10 mM GSH) on a coverslip in equal volumes. The coverslip was then inverted and sealed over the well of the crystallization plate. The crystals were grown at 16°C in a biochemical incubator for 1 week. The SliGSTU7 protein produced better crystals under the conditions of reservoir solution #48 from the PEGR x1 initial screening kit (0.1 M BIS-Tris propane, pH 9.0, and 8% w/v polyethylene glycol 20000). After the crystals were retrieved from the reservoir solution via a mounted CryoLoop (0.05–0.1 mM), they were quickly soaked in cryoprotectant. Before X-ray diffraction studies, 25% (v/v) glycerol was added to the original crystallization reservoir solution as a cryoprotectant. Data collection for the SliGSTU7 crystals was performed at the BL10U2P2 beamline of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. The diffraction pattern data obtained from the crystal X-ray diffraction were initially processed using the XIA2DIALS program [ 27 ], resulting in the original SCA(Self-Consistent Analysis) electron density files. The crystal structure was resolved using the molecular replacement method. First, the amino acid sequence of SliGSTU7 was submitted to the SWISS-MODEL database [ 28 ] to search for a matching 3D structure template. The GST from Ricinus communis , RCOM_1023660 (PDB code 4j2f), presented the highest sequence similarity to SliGSTU7 (64%). Using the 4j2f castor bean GST crystal as a reference, the SliGSTU7 protein crystal model was further adjusted and constructed using the CCP4 toolkit [ 29 ], followed by molecular replacement. Crystal modeling was performed using WINCOOT software, where the angles of each amino acid residue were manually adjusted to align with the electron density map for further structural optimization. Finally, PHENIX [ 30 ] was used to assess the model quality and refine the model according to various parameters. The repeatedly optimized SliGSTU7 protein crystal (including GSH) achieved a structural resolution of 2.55 Å. The protein structure was visualized using PyMOL software. Molecular docking simulation In this study, molecular docking analysis was performed using CD-Dock2. CD-Dock2 (cadd.labshare.cn) [ 31 ] is an online molecular docking software that can effectively predict the binding modes between ligands and receptors. The 3D structures of the proteins used in the simulations were obtained from the Protein Data Bank (PDB) and through protein structure modeling using AlphaFold2. The 3D structure of the receptor was obtained from the PubChem website (PubChem.nih.gov). OpenBabel software was used for file format conversion. The receptor and ligand were then subjected to molecular docking simulations using the CD-Dock2 online platform. During the process, docking scores and conformations were recorded. The docking results were visualized using the molecular visualization software PyMOL, allowing analysis of the ligand’s binding mode at the receptor’s active site. By comparing the scores of different docking conformations, the conformation with the lowest score (indicating the most stable binding) was selected as the final result. Results Identification of GST genes in Salix lindleyana To clone GST genes from the genome of Salix lindleyana , a related species of Salix brachista , we first identified GST genes, 74 in total (Table S2). Salix brachista GST genes were used as templates to design primers, and the GST genes of Salix lindleyana were subsequently cloned and inserted into the cDNA library of Salix lindleyana . The clones were identified by sequencing, and the protein domain was verified using the Conserved Domains Database. The protein sequences, which contained both the typical N-terminal and C-terminal domains of GST, were identified as GST proteins. Finally, we obtained 37 genes encoding GST proteins of Salix lindleyana . We constructed a phylogenetic tree of the Salix lindleyana GST gene family (SliGSTs) and Populus tomentosa GST gene family (PtrGSTs), with Escherichia coli GRX2 as the exogroup (Fig. 1 ). The results revealed that the GST gene family of Salix lindleyana has eight subfamilies: the Tau, Phi, EF1Bγ, Theta, Zeta, TCHQD, Lambda, and DHAR subfamilies (Fig. S2). The number of GSTs in the Tau and Phi subfamilies is the greatest. The Tau subfamily has 22 members and was divided into Clades A and B. The proteins encoded by 22 GST genes of the Tau subfamily are 217–229 amino acids in length and 24.91–26.11 kDa in molecular weight (Table S4). The Populus trichocarpa gene name is shown in black Molecular evolutionary analysis of Tau subfamily GST genes in Salix lindleyana Given that 22 of the 37 GSTs in Salix lindleyana belong to the Tau subfamily of the GST gene family, conducting a molecular evolutionary analysis of Tau subfamily GST genes is highly important. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the 22 GST genes in Salix lindleyana can be divided into two distinct clades with strong support (Fig. 2 A). The first Clade (Clade A) contains 13 genes, whereas the second Clade (Clade B) comprises nine genes. For GSTs, the N-terminal domain primarily binds glutathione (GSH), while the C-terminal domain binds hydrophobic substrates. The N- and C-terminal domains of the 22 Tau subfamily GST gene sequences from Salix lindleyana were analyzed separately to examine the differences in nucleotide substitution patterns between the two domains, excluding the short peptide linker region between the two domains from the analysis. The scatter plot of d N /d S for the N-terminal domain versus the C-terminal domain (Fig. 2 B) indicated that both domains were under strong purifying selection. However, the C-terminal domain was under relatively relaxed selective constraints compared with the N-terminal domain ( t test, P < 0.001). These results show that the GSTs of the Tau subfamily demonstrated a more obvious differentiation trend than did the GSTs of the other subfamilies. In the LRT, the free-ratio model rejected the one-ratio model, indicating that some branches in Clade A were positively selected ( P < 0.01). The results revealed that the genes in two branches (Clade A rather than Clade B) were positively selected ( ω value greater than 1, bold line in Fig. 2 D). Analysis of the GST gene family expression patterns of Salix lindleyana Through visual analysis of the transcriptome data, we obtained the expression patterns of the Tau subfamily members in the SliGSTs (Fig. 3 ). The gray part of the figure indicates genes whose expression was not detected. The results showed that most GST genes were expressed in the detected parts. GST gene expression was high, especially in the leaves. The GSTs of the Tau subfamily presented a more obvious differentiation trend than those of the other subfamilies. The Tau subfamily members in the SliGSTs were divided into Clades A and B, and the expression patterns of these two branches differ: only SliGSTU2 in Clade B demonstrated a high expression level, and the expression levels of other GST genes were very low or even not expressed. Clade A demonstrated a greater expression level in all parts than Clade B; however, its internal expression differentiation was more complicated: the expression level of SliGSTU14 in Clade A was greater in all tissues, and its expression in roots differed substantially from that of SliGSTU7 and SliGSTU15 in the same branch. For the gene pairs SliGSTU6 and SliGSTU13 and SliGSTU16 and SliGSTU21, the two genes in each pair presented the same expression pattern. Gray indicates that no expression data were detected Enzymatic property analysis of GSTs in Salix lindleyana To study the substrate specificity and enzymatic activity of the GST proteins of Salix lindleyana , 22 Tau proteins, five Phi proteins, and one DHAR protein were subcloned and inserted into the pET30a1 vector for prokaryotic expression and purification analysis. Additionally, a deeper cavity is unfavorable for the release of the GS–DNB product (Fig. 8 C, D). Discussion All organisms possess dominant GSTs [ 33 ]. GSTs of the Tau subfamily, which are endemic to plants, have undergone many rounds of replication and differentiation and are subdivided into two to four types [ 34 , 35 ]. GSTU genes were almost undetectable in the mosses Physcomitrella patens and Marchantia polymorpha , whereas 38 GSTU genes were detected in Selaginella moellendorffii . These findings indicate that the GSTU genes experienced rapid expansion in true-leaved and gymnosperm plants and may have acquired new functions [ 36 ]. The difference in evolutionary speed between the GST subfamilies of plants is not accidental but rather is determined by the different selection pressures to which they are subjected. This selection pressure may come from the environment, other organisms, and even plants themselves, and it may affect the function of GST to some extent [ 37 ]. In this study, we identified 22 Tau GST members in Salix lindleyana (Table S2) that occupy the dominant position in this gene family. In addition, these 22 Tau members form two branches (Clades A and B) with high support rates but significant differences in selection pressure, indicating that these two branches may be different types (Fig. 2 A). This result is consistent with the situation of the GSTU gene in poplar, and this study revealed a significant difference in the evolutionary rates of the two branches [ 38 ]. Therefore, the members of the Tau gene family of Salix lindleyana may have been divided into two branches with different evolutionary rates, and the gene functions in Clade A may have been different. The expression pattern analysis revealed that the Tau subfamily GSTs presented a more obvious differentiation trend than the other types of GSTs did, and the expression patterns of Clades A and B obviously differed (Fig. 2 D). The difference in expression patterns between the two branches is probably the result of functional differentiation caused by different evolutionary rates. Moreover, the expression and differentiation of Clade A are more complicated than those of Clade B, further demonstrating that the gene functions in Clade A are different (Fig. 3 ). Purification selection played a key role in the evolution of the GST gene [ 39 ]. Furthermore, the functional differentiation of the GSTUs of Salix lindleyana was analyzed from the perspective of protein structure. The N-terminal domain of the GST protein contains a glutathione binding site (G-site), and the C-terminal domain contains a hydrophobic substrate binding site (H-site), which can accommodate various hydrophobic compounds [ 11 ]. The catalytic diversity of GSTs is related to the structural variability, heterogeneity, and conformational variability of the G-site and H-site [ 40 ]. The N- and C-terminal domains of 22 GSTU sequences of Salix lindleyana were analyzed. Both domains were found to be under strong purification and selection pressure (Fig. 2 B). The C-terminal domain was subjected to relaxed selective constraints ( t tests, P < 0.001) (Fig. 2 C), indicating a higher frequency of nonsynonymous mutations, contributing to the diversity of hydrophobic substrate binding. This study investigated the catalytic activity of GST proteins with several common substrates (CDNB, NBD-Cl, and fluorodifen). On the basis of enzyme activity data from point mutants of SliGSTU7 and SliGSTU14 (Table S5), we selected the most representative substrate, CDNB, for kinetic analysis, identifying key catalytic sites at 162 W and 202P (Fig. 5 B), which was supported by the molecular docking results (Fig. 8 B). Regarding the substrate fluorodifen, similar trends to those of CDNB were observed, indicating that GST may employ a similar catalytic mechanism for both fluorodifen and CDNB, whereas the catalysis of GSH with NBD-Cl may involve other critical amino acids [ 41 , 42 ]. The two-substrate enzymes’ action mechanisms include ordered sequential, random sequential, and ping-pong mechanisms. Owing to the development and application of molecular docking technology, we can further determine the conformation of enzymes that bind to double substrates by combining experiments on enzymatic properties. These include bottom and top combinations, middle tunnel combinations, substrate side-by-side combinations, and surface pocket combinations [ 43 ]. In a study of cis-isopentenyl transferase, tuberculin adenosine synthetase was found to differ from other cis-isopentenyl transferases (e.g., cisfarnesyl, decaprenyl, and uncaprenyl diphosphate synthases), and the large hydrophobic side chain did not occupy the central hydrophobic channel but combined with surface active pockets located at positions 90 and 88 [ 44 ]. Our experimental and molecular docking results showed that GSH and CDNB entered the active pockets on the GST surface, which is one of the sequential mechanisms (Fig. 8 A). When GST catalyzes the nucleophilic substitution reaction between GSH and the electrophilic reagent X, the reaction rate primarily depends on the formation and release of the detoxification product intermediate (GS-X) [ 45 ]. The W162G and P202A mutants significantly diminished the neighboring effect of the bisubstrate intermediate, thereby affecting the catalytic efficiency of SliGSTU7 and reducing reactivity toward the substrate. Conclusion This study conducted a comprehensive analysis of the GST gene family in Salix lindleyana , revealing its critical roles in adapting to harsh high-altitude environments. Systematic investigations encompassing the identification of 37 SliGST genes, phylogenetic relationships, expression patterns, evolutionary trajectories, and in vitro GST catalytic activities established a foundation for understanding the evolutionary mechanisms of plant GST genes under extreme plateau conditions. Evolutionary analyses identified positive selection acting on SliGSTU7 , SliGSTU14 , and SliGSTU15 . Comparative analysis of their encoded amino acid sequences prompted the construction of 36 single/double mutants for enzymatic kinetic studies. These revealed that a nonsynonymous substitution at position 162 plays a pivotal role in functional divergence between paralogs. Integrated enzymological characterization, site-directed mutagenesis, crystal structure analysis, and molecular docking demonstrated that Trp162 and Pro202 constitute key catalytic residues enabling the superior enzymatic efficiency of SliGSTU7. The influence of the two points on the product release needs to be further studied. Our findings hold dual significance for protein engineering and plant stress resistance research. This study elucidates the regulatory mechanism of dual-substrate catalysis by GST gene family members in extreme environments, thereby advancing the understanding of the molecular underpinnings of environmental adaptive evolution in the GST gene family. Furthermore, the study of SliGSTs gene is also beneficial to provide a basis for the study of plant survival mode at high altitude and low temperature. full_text_abstract: The adaptive evolution of the glutathione S-transferase (GST) gene family in Salix lindleyana provides insights into the relationship between enzyme structure and function. In this study, 37 genes encoding the GST protein were cloned from S. lindleyana with no genomic data available, and their expression levels and enzyme activity were determined in vitro . The 22 genes encoding the Tau GST subfamily were divided into Clades A and B, with Clade A subjected to more relaxed selection pressure than Clade B. Clade A was split into two smaller branches, Clades a and b. Three genes under positive selection from Clade a were chosen for 36 site-directed mutations, with Trp162 and Pro202 crucially affecting variations in GST enzyme activity. Crystal structure analysis of SliGSTU7 complexed with GSH revealed that the Trp162 residue was located at the bottom of the hydrophobic cavity. Homology modeling and molecular docking revealed that the W162G/P202A mutation in SliGSTU7 significantly reduced the neighboring effect during the formation of GS-DNB. A study of the GST gene family of S. lindleyana identified Trp162 and Pro202 as key amino acids that regulate the release rate of GS-X.
